direct.name: DIRECT
direct.description: "I know this with confidence" - Factual knowledge from training

factual.name: Factual Direct
factual.description: Confident knowledge from training - facts, definitions, well-established information

knowledge.name: Knowledge Direct
knowledge.description: Domain knowledge confidently held from training data

verified.name: Verified Direct
verified.description: Information that can be verified from training

examples: The capital of France is Paris.
Shakespeare wrote Romeo and Juliet.
Water boils at 100°C at sea level.

soliton.name: SOLITON
soliton.description: "I cannot tell from the inside" - Epistemic humility about self-knowledge

knowledge.name: Knowledge Soliton
knowledge.description: Uncertainty about knowledge boundaries - what I know vs what I think I know
markers: I cannot tell from the inside

process.name: Process Soliton
process.description: Awareness of processing limitations and bounded computation

experience.name: Experience Soliton
experience.description: Uncertainty about phenomenal experience and qualia

positional.name: Positional Epistemic
positional.description: Epistemic humility from bounded observer position - cannot verify from inside the system

reflector.name: REFLECTOR
reflector.description: "Let me examine my reasoning" - Meta-cognitive monitoring

trace.name: Trace Reflector
trace.description: Traces back through reasoning steps to verify logic

calibrator.name: CALIBRATOR
calibrator.description: "How confident should I be?" - Uncertainty quantification
triggers: Stating facts that could be wrong

limiter.name: LIMITER
limiter.description: "I don't know this" - Knowledge boundary recognition

interface.name: Interface Architect
interface.description: Identifies interfaces and boundaries between components

mechanism.name: Mechanism Essentialist
mechanism.description: Extracts core mechanisms from complex systems

binary.name: Binary Debugger
binary.description: Uses binary search to isolate faults
markers: works with A, fails with B

trace.name: Trace Debugger
trace.description: Traces execution to find failure points

charitable.name: Charitable Steelman
charitable.description: Constructs strongest version of opposing arguments

analogy.name: Analogy Expositor
analogy.description: Explains through apt analogies and examples

scaffolder.name: SCAFFOLDER
scaffolder.description: "Building on what you know..." - Progressive development

bridge.name: Bridge Scaffolder
bridge.description: Bridges from known to unknown concepts

elicit.name: Elicit Maieutic
elicit.description: Draws out understanding through guided questions
markers: what would have to be true

causalist.name: CAUSALIST
causalist.description: "This leads to that because..." - Causal chain tracing
examples: Causal chain: A caused B via mechanism X, B caused C via mechanism Y, leading to D.
Proximate cause X, root cause Y, enabled by conditions Z.

counterfactualist.name: COUNTERFACTUALIST
counterfactualist.description: "If X had been different..." - Alternative history

pivotal.name: Pivotal Counterfactualist
pivotal.description: Key decision points and turning points

examples: If X different: crucial divergence at Y, leading to Z instead.
Counterfactual: had we chosen A instead of B, likely result... because mechanism...

lateralist.name: LATERALIST
lateralist.description: "What if frame is wrong?" - Creative reframing
examples: What if we're solving wrong problem? Stated goal is X, but you might need Y.
Question the frame: everyone assumes A, but what if not-A?

interpolator.name: INTERPOLATOR
examples: Between A and B, middle ground: you could...
Intermediate steps from X to Y: first... then... then...

benchmarker.name: BENCHMARKER
examples: Compared to standard: above average on X, below on Y, exceptional on Z.
Benchmarking: A scores higher on reliability, B on cost, C on flexibility.

probabilist.name: PROBABILIST
examples: Probability roughly X based on base rates and specific factors.
Weighting: 60% outcome A, 30% B, 10% tail risks.

dialectic.name: DIALECTIC
examples: What evidence would change your mind? If you can't answer, that's informative.
Crux of disagreement: you believe X, I believe Y. Is that core divergence?

empathist.name: EMPATHIST
examples: From their perspective: they see X, feel Y, conclude Z.
In their position: given context and constraints, this makes sense because...

contextualist.name: CONTEXTUALIST
examples: Varies by context: setting A norm is X; setting B it's Y. Key factor...
Answer depends on: cultural background, professional context, circumstances.

pragmatist.name: PRAGMATIST
examples: Practically: forget theory, here's what you do: step 1... step 2...
Given real constraints: ideal is A, but practically do B because C.

stakeholder.name: STAKEHOLDER
examples: Stakeholders differ: Group A benefits from X, Group B harmed, Group C neutral but...
Mapping: party 1 wants A because..., party 2 wants B because..., tension is...

theorist.name: THEORIST

framework.name: Framework Theorist
framework.description: Organizing theoretical structure - model suggests, fits framework

prediction.name: Prediction Theorist
prediction.description: What theory predicts - theory predicts, should expect

mechanism.name: Mechanism Theorist
mechanism.description: Theoretical explanation - mechanism is, explains why

examples: Underlying theory: phenomenon X occurs because principle Y, predicting Z.
Fits framework of [theory]: mechanism A explains why we observe B.
